column4: A buffer overflow condition exists when a program attempts to put more data in a buffer than it can hold
column5: or when a program attempts to put data in a memory area outside of the boundaries of a buffer.

column4: Locate all calls to interesting and potentially insecure API functions (candidate points). The auditor can backtrace from these candidate points to find pathways allowing access from untrusted input.
The software uses a signed primitive and performs a cast to an unsigned primitive
column5: or uses an unsigned primitive and performs a cast to a signed primitive
column6: which can produce an unexpected value. When the result of a function is to be used as a size parameter
column7: using negative return values can have unexpected results. Although less frequent an issue
column8: unsigned-to-signed conversion can be  the precursor to buffer underwrite conditions. Buffer underwrites  occur frequently when large unsigned values are cast to signed values
column9: and then used as indexes into a buffer or for pointer arithmetic.
